Linear DRO Methods

exception dro.src.linear_model.chi2_dro.Chi2DROError[source]

Bases: Exception

Base exception class for errors in Chi-squared DRO model.

class dro.src.linear_model.chi2_dro.Chi2DRO(input_dim: int, model_type: str = 'svm', fit_intercept: bool = True, solver: str = 'MOSEK')[source]

Bases: BaseLinearDRO

Chi-squared Distributionally Robust Optimization (chi2-DRO) model.

This model minimizes a chi-squared robust loss function for both regression and classification.

input_dim

Dimensionality of the input features.

Type:

int

model_type

Model type indicator (e.g., ‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression with L2-loss, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression with L1-loss).

Type:

str

fit_intercept

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

Type:

bool, default = True

solver

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

Type:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

eps

Robustness parameter for DRO.

Type:

float

Reference: <https://www.jmlr.org/papers/volume20/17-750/17-750.pdf>

Initialize the Chi2-DRO model with specified input dimension and model type.

Parameters:

  • input_dim (int) – Dimension of the input features.

  • model_type (str) – Type of model (‘svm’, ‘logistic’, ‘ols’, ‘lad’).

  • fit_intercept (bool, default = True) – Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

  • solver (str, default = 'MOSEK') – Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’

update(config: Dict[str, Any] = {})[source]

Update the model configuration.

Parameters:

config (dict) – Configuration dictionary containing ‘eps’ key for robustness parameter.

Raises:

Chi2DROError – If ‘eps’ is provided but is not a non-negative float.

fit(X: ndarray, y: ndarray) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit the model using CVXPY to solve the Chi2 distributionally robust optimization problem.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Input feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

Returns:

Model parameters dictionary with ‘theta’ key.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

Chi2DROError – If the optimization problem fails to solve.

evaluate(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, theta: ndarray, fast: True)[source]

Fast evaluate the true model performance for the obtained theta efficiently from data unbiased

worst_distribution(X: ndarray, y: ndarray) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Compute the worst-case distribution.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Input feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

Returns:

Dictionary containing ‘sample_pts’ and ‘weight’ keys for worst-case distribution.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

Chi2DROError – If the worst-case distribution optimization fails.

Reference: <https://jmlr.org/papers/volume20/17-750/17-750.pdf> (Equation (8))

exception dro.src.linear_model.cvar_dro.CVaRDROError[source]

Bases: Exception

Base exception class for errors in CVaR DRO model.

class dro.src.linear_model.cvar_dro.CVaRDRO(input_dim: int, model_type: str = 'svm', fit_intercept: bool = True, solver: str = 'MOSEK', alpha: float = 1.0)[source]

Bases: BaseLinearDRO

Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) Distributionally Robust Optimization (DRO) model.

This model minimizes a robust loss function for both regression and classification tasks under a CVaR constraint.

Attributes: input_dim (int): Dimensionality of the input features. model_type (str): Model type indicator (‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression). fit_intercept (bool, default = True): Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered). solver (str, default = ‘MOSEK’): Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’. alpha (float): Risk level for the CVaR constraint. threshold_val (float): Threshold value from the optimization.

Reference: <https://www.risk.net/journal-risk/2161159/optimization-conditional-value-risk>

Initialize the CVaR DRO model with specified input dimension, model type, and alpha parameter.

Parameters:

  • input_dim (int) – Dimension of the input features.

  • model_type (str) – Type of model (‘svm’, ‘logistic’, ‘ols’).

  • fit_intercept (bool, default = True) – Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

  • solver (str, default = 'MOSEK') – Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’

  • alpha (float) – Risk level for CVaR (default is 1.0).

update(config: Dict[str, Any]) → None[source]

Update the model configuration.

Parameters:

config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary containing ‘alpha’ key for CVaR risk level.

Raises:

CVaRDROError – If ‘alpha’ is not in the valid range (0, 1].

fit(X: ndarray, y: ndarray) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit the model using CVXPY to solve the robust optimization problem under CVaR constraint.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

Returns:

Model parameters dictionary with ‘theta’ and ‘threshold’ keys.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

CVaRDROError – If the optimization problem fails to solve.

worst_distribution(X: ndarray, y: ndarray, precision: float = 1e-05) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Compute the worst-case distribution based on CVaR constraint.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Input feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

  • precision (float) – The perturbation amount in case when the loss is too insignificant to count.

Returns:

Dictionary containing ‘sample_pts’ and ‘weight’ keys for worst-case distribution.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

CVaRDROError – If the worst-case distribution calculation fails.

exception dro.src.linear_model.kl_dro.KLDROError[source]

Bases: Exception

Base exception class for errors in KL-DRO model.

class dro.src.linear_model.kl_dro.KLDRO(input_dim: int, model_type: str = 'svm', fit_intercept: bool = True, solver: str = 'MOSEK', eps: float = 0.0)[source]

Bases: BaseLinearDRO

Kullback-Leibler divergence-based Distributionally Robust Optimization (KL-DRO) model.

This model minimizes a KL-robust loss function for both regression and classification.

input_dim

Dimensionality of the input features.

Type:

int

model_type

Model type indicator (e.g., ‘svm’ for SVM, ‘logistic’ for Logistic Regression, ‘ols’ for Linear Regression with L2-loss, ‘lad’ for Linear Regression with L1-loss).

Type:

str

fit_intercept

Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

Type:

bool, default = True

solver

Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’.

Type:

str, default = ‘MOSEK’

eps

Robustness parameter for KL-DRO.

Type:

float

dual_variable

Dual variable value from the optimization problem.

Type:

Optional[float]

Reference: <https://optimization-online.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/3677.pdf>

Initialize the KL-DRO model with specified input dimension and model type.

Parameters:

  • input_dim (int) – Dimension of the input features.

  • model_type (str) – Type of model (‘svm’, ‘logistic’, ‘ols’, ‘lad’).

  • fit_intercept (bool, default = True) – Whether to calculate the intercept for this model. If set to False, no intercept will be used in calculations (i.e. data is expected to be centered).

  • solver (str, default = 'MOSEK') – Optimization solver to solve the problem, default = ‘MOSEK’

  • eps (float) – Ambiguity size for the KL constraint (default is 0.0).

update(config: Dict[str, Any]) → None[source]

Update the model configuration.

Parameters:

config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary containing ‘eps’ key for robustness parameter.

Raises:

KLDROError – If ‘eps’ is provided but is not a non-negative float.

fit(X: ndarray, y: ndarray) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Fit the model using CVXPY to solve the robust optimization problem with KL constraint.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

Returns:

Model parameters dictionary with ‘theta’ and ‘dual’ keys.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

KLDROError – If the optimization problem fails to solve.

worst_distribution(X: ndarray, y: ndarray) → Dict[str, Any][source]

Compute the worst-case distribution based on KL divergence.

Parameters:

  • X (np.ndarray) – Input feature matrix with shape (n_samples, n_features).

  • y (np.ndarray) – Target vector with shape (n_samples,).

Returns:

Dictionary containing ‘sample_pts’ and ‘weight’ keys for worst-case distribution.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Raises:

KLDROError – If the worst-case distribution optimization fails.
